name: NPR
text:
Missouri Gov. Mike Parson, who often appears at functions maskless and has said that "you don't need government to tell you to wear a dang mask," has tested positive for the coronavirus. His wife Teresa has, too.
https://t.co/sAv8af54gL

name: NPR
text:
RT @idislikestephen: Since April, NPR Music has been updating a playlist of new songs we adore, called Press Pause And Hit Play. Today, we added one of my favorite tracks of 2020: @chrisstapleton's "Starting Over," an uncluttered song about love in a messy, complicated world.

https://t.co/KAcfyERxld

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRItsBeenAMin: This school year is proving to be like no other. So what's the experience been like for the teachers trying to make school happen? 

In this podcast episode, teachers across the U.S. share their experience with @samsanders.

LISTEN üîä https://t.co/WlMXzWhBbk

name: NPR
text:
President Trump on Wednesday declined to promise a peaceful transfer of power if he is not declared the winner in November. "We're going to have to see what happens," he said.
https://t.co/eDqrktYIeB

name: NPR
text:
Reacting to a report that the FDA plans to tighten requirements for emergency use authorization of any coronavirus vaccine to better ensure its safety and effectiveness, President Trump said:

"That sounds like a political move."  
https://t.co/i5vvicnyEq

name: NPR
text:
If TikTok were banned for 2 months, up to half its U.S. users would quit permanently. If banned for 6 months, 90% of users would never return.

That's according to a court filing urging a federal judge to halt Trump's TikTok ban from taking effect Sunday.
https://t.co/EsgQlovlgZ

name: NPR
text:
The University of California admitted at least 64 students over more qualified applicants due to their connections to staff or donors, a state audit found.

One babysat a former admissions director‚Äôs coworker.

Another had parents promising a big donation.
https://t.co/YPB8epwXz3

name: NPR
text:
At least one Louisville police officer has been shot as protesters marched to demand justice for Breonna Taylor following a limited grand jury indictment. Police officials offered no details about the shooting.
 https://t.co/BDWCEeGVd8

name: NPR
text:
Citigroup estimates the economy would see a $5 trillion boost in the next five years if the U.S. were to address key areas of discrimination against Black Americans.
https://t.co/yJEFb3VMGT

name: NPR
text:
Elena, una jueza de Buenos Aires, recibi√≥ el expediente en 2015: era la primera vez que ten√≠a que decidir sobre los derechos de un ser que no era humano.

Escuchen la historia en nuestro podcast en espa√±ol, @radioambulante. https://t.co/VfcaeET0ww

name: NPR
text:
46% of Americans say they're having "serious financial problems" amid the pandemic, a new NPR poll finds. Nearly 1 out of 3 respondents had used up all or most of their savings.
https://t.co/n88Wrj9Au2

name: NPR
text:
More than 17 million people ‚Äî the most ever recorded during wildfire season ‚Äî live in counties where air quality reached levels deemed "very unhealthy" or "hazardous" so far this year.

And that unhealthy air lingered twice as long as the recent average.
https://t.co/mRpbrOz0M9

name: NPR
text:
President Trump warned tech companies he is "watching them very closely during this election cycle" as his administration proposed stripping online platforms of long-held legal protections.
https://t.co/WGB1f1K11F

name: NPR
text:
A report released by the prestigious Curtis Institute of Music found that violinist Lara St. John's account of being raped and sexually abused by her teacher more than 3 decades ago is credible.
https://t.co/FrosuWk7Mt

name: NPR
text:
Dua Lipa released her second album, "Future Nostalgia," just weeks after the world went into lockdown. The sure-footedness of her pop seems like an ironic counterpoint to the calamity of this year.
https://t.co/ogQUNqQ8oO

name: NPR
text:
In her new book, ‚ÄúConditional Citizens,‚Äù Laila Lalami says Americans who don't enjoy full rights because of their identities want the U.S. to succeed.

But they can't avoid the chasm between our purported values and the realities of oppression, she says.
https://t.co/iO2VaJVh0E

name: NPR
text:
Vietnam's so-called "Intergenerational Self Help Clubs" encourage people 60 and above to find solutions to their own challenges ‚Äî from finding a microloan to learning to play the drums.

"Older people are not helpless."
https://t.co/2WiHeYnIcU

name: NPR
text:
1 in 6 households reported missing or delaying paying bills just so they could buy food, an NPR poll finds. Many are having trouble paying rent ‚Äî especially African Americans and Latinos.
https://t.co/CYUKONK2do

name: NPR
text: Chris Anderson, an elections officer in Seminole County, Florida, has had to get creative in order to save his department money while ensuring residents can cast their vote safely. https://t.co/nuHMMUsYwS

name: NPR
text: Franzo and Marina King had a literal religious experience when they heard John Coltrane play for their first wedding anniversary, Five decades later, they're still preaching their gospel at the Coltrane Church in San Francisco. https://t.co/n76fwS3Aqk

name: NPR
text:
Officials say North Korean troops shot to death a South Korean fisheries official after he was found floating in North Korean waters.

President Moon Jae-in called the killing "a shocking incident that cannot be tolerated."
https://t.co/Sa42CeDEwc
